final_answer.precision_note: Result to 3 significant figures, based on supplied volumes and NaOH concentration.

method: The titration data give the volume of NaOH (23.40 cm³) and its concentration (0.150 mol dm⁻³). Converting the volume to dm³ (0.02340 dm³) yields moles of NaOH as c·V = 0.150 × 0.02340 = 0.00351 mol. The balanced equation shows a 2:1 stoichiometry between NaOH and H₂SO₄, so the moles of H₂SO₄ present are half the moles of NaOH: 0.00351 / 2 = 0.001755 mol. Dividing this by the volume of the acid sample (25.00 cm³ = 0.02500 dm³) gives the concentration of H₂SO₄: 0.001755 / 0.02500 = 0.0702 mol dm⁻³. All calculations retain the three‑significant‑figure precision of the input data.
checks: Verify moles NaOH = 0.150 mol dm-3 × 0.02340 dm3 = 0.00351 mol.
Check concentration = 0.001755 mol / 0.02500 dm3 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.
